awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Redshirt in Engineering Consortium
awd_abstract_narration:
Low-income students are underrepresented in engineering and more likely to struggle in engineering programs.  Research has found that increasing first and second-year retention enhances the ability of academically talented low-income students to successfully graduate with engineering degrees. In this collaborative research project six institutions will replicate, improve, and test a model of student success originally developed at the University of Colorado, Boulder. The model is designed to increase the retention, success, and graduation of low-income (Pell-eligible) academically talented students from underserved populations. The project will make scholarship awards to 800 students across a consortium of the six partner institutions. To support the students, the project will adapt and implement an ecosystem of high quality evidence-based curricular and co-curricular activities. Members of the consortium are: the University of Colorado, Boulder; the University of Washington; Washington State University; Boise State University; the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign; and the University of California, San Diego.  

The Redshirt in Engineering Consortium is committed to propagating the "Redshirt" model, which focuses primarily on the first-year of college and consists of intrusive academic advising, an innovative first-year academic curriculum, community building, and career awareness. The term "redshirt" refers to the idea of providing an extra year of preparation for the rigors of engineering curricula. A quantitative and qualitative mixed methods research study will examine the implementation of the model under different conditions and with different student populations.  A comparative longitudinal study will examine differences in expected student outcomes between scholarship recipients and similar students who are pursuing engineering degrees.  The primary analytic approach for the ethnographic research will be the Constant Comparative Analysis, which will involve concurrent engagement in data collection and data analysis.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Starting in 2016, this award provided scholarships to 125 engineering students at the University of Colorado at Boulder (CUB) and supported CUB's participation in the Redshirt in Engineering Consortium.  The Consortium aimed to share best practices in supporting academically talented but underprepared engineering students from underserved backgrounds, including through an extra "Redshirt" year of university-level preparation for the engineering curriculum. The Consortium included existing programs at CUB, the University of Washington and Washington State University and new programs at Boise State University, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and the University of California San Diego. Consortium members collaborated in studying the influence of program elements on student success. CUB's version of the Redshirt program is known as the "GoldShirt" program, reflecting the school colors of black and gold. 

As implemented at CUB, key components of the Redshirt model included (1) holistic admissions evaluation allowing a pathway to engineering for academically talented students who had gaps in their preparation to study engineering, (2) an expected five-year time to degree; (3) a two-week summer bridge program to accelerate the adjustment to college; (3) intensive advising, especially during the freshman and sophomore years; (4) community-building and networking support; (5) faculty mentoring; and (6) financial support including NSF-funded scholarships.  Financial support was a critical program element, given the expected five-year timeline for earning a degree. 

NSF S-STEM scholarships were awarded to members of five groups of GoldShirt students, with the first cohort starting in fall 2016 and the final cohort in fall 2020.  Scholarship recipients were selected primarily based on having unmet financial need.  Students received the NSF scholarships for their first four semesters as a supplement to other financial aid. Each student was assigned a faculty mentor, with more than 30 CUB faculty participating in that role. As of May 2022, 33 of the scholars had graduated from CUB and 70 more were continuing their studies, for an overall retention rate of 82%. 

Throughout the award period, CUB faculty and staff exchanged ideas, experiences, and resources with Consortium partners. This occurred through in-person meetings in the first and third years of the award, bimonthly or monthly conference calls, and an organized file sharing site. Contributions to the Consortium from CUB covered elements of the GoldShirt summer bridge program; first-year course materials; and information about peer mentoring, residential life programs and CUB's recruiting and admissions process. CUB administered beginning- and end-of-year surveys to all first year GoldShirt students to contribute to the Consortium's assessment efforts, which were led by the Center for Evaluation and Research for STEM Equity at the University of Washington. 

With assistance from other Consortium partners, CUB researchers studied the experience of scholars in the six Redshirt programs following the completion of their first year, including adaptations in residential and learning environments during the COVID 19 pandemic. Engineering students often face academic challenges during their second and third years, which were heightened after the onset of the pandemic. Furthermore, within the Consortium, students at this stage were transitioning away from Redshirt-focused programming with more of their time and effort directed within their individual engineering majors. Research led by Drs. Daniel Knight, Bev Louie, and Janet Tsai at CUB included focus groups and individual interviews with students at the six Redshirt institutions. In the final year of the award, the research was expanded to include photo elicitation methods to allow students to better describe their experiences and settings. From their research, Daniel Knight and Janet Tsai found that inconsistencies related to COVID pandemic living and learning environments hindered identity development and community building, and that Redshirt students often struggled in large engineering math and science courses, particularly during high-stakes testing. On the other hand, they found that extra- and co-curricular activities such as clubs, affinity groups, and research experiences helped create a sense of belonging in engineering that went beyond Redshirt communities. Notably, Redshirt communities served as important resources for students throughout the pandemic, even with remote learning and virtual summer bridge programs.

This award has helped CUB increase the enrollment and retention of students from under-resourced backgrounds and thus enhance the diversity of its student body. CUB helped three new institutions gain experience with the Redshirt model. In exchanging information, the six Consortium partners increased their understanding of best practices for serving the targeted pool of students, beginning with recruiting and admissions. Faculty mentors gained greater understanding of Redshirt students' challenges and potential. At CUB, the lessons learned from the GoldShirt program influenced practices in other STEM fields and the office of admissions, helping move the admissions process to a more holistic evaluation of academic potential. The GoldShirt program has provided access and support to talented students who previously might have been bypassed for admission to engineering, helping to expand their opportunities and broaden perspectives in the engineering workforce.
